title: 113_hr4977
content: The Act may be cited as the "Creating Options for Veterans Expedited Recovery Act" or the "COVER Act". It establishes duties related to veterans' expedited recovery. The Veterans Expedited Recovery Commission is established to examine the efficacy of therapy for mental health illnesses in veterans and improve wellness outcomes. They will also conduct surveys to assess veterans' experiences with medical assistance for mental health issues within the Department of Veterans Affairs and non-Department facilities. The Veterans Expedited Recovery Commission will examine the efficacy of therapy for mental health illnesses in veterans, including preferences for treatments, experiences with alternative therapies, prevalence of prescription medication, and outreach efforts by the Secretary. The Veterans Expedited Recovery Commission will assess benefits and treatments for veterans' mental health, including alternative therapies like music therapy, equine therapy, service dog training, yoga therapy, acupuncture, meditation, outdoor sports therapy, hyperbaric oxygen therapy, and accelerated resolution therapy. The Veterans Expedited Recovery Commission will study the approval of compensation claims for mental health issues in veterans of Operation Enduring Freedom, Operation Iraqi Freedom, and Operation New Dawn, including alternative therapies like accelerated resolution therapy. The Veterans Expedited Recovery Commission will study the approval of compensation claims for mental health issues in veterans of recent military operations, including alternative therapies like accelerated resolution therapy. SEC. 3. MEMBERSHIP. The Veterans Expedited Recovery Commission consists of 10 members appointed by various leaders, with at least one veteran in each group. Members must meet specific qualifications. The Veterans Expedited Recovery Commission consists of 10 members appointed by various leaders, with at least one veteran in each group. Members must be individuals of recognized standing in the medical community with a background in treating mental health, as well as individuals with experience working with the military and veteran population. The President designates a chairman from the Commission members, who serve for the life of the Commission. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment, and appointments must be made within 90 days of the enactment of the Act. The Veterans Expedited Recovery Commission has powers outlined in Section 4. The Veterans Expedited Recovery Commission shall hold initial and regular meetings, may conduct hearings, and gather necessary information from federal agencies to fulfill its responsibilities. The Veterans Expedited Recovery Commission may gather information from various organizations, keep accurate records, and request personnel from federal agencies as needed. The Veterans Expedited Recovery Commission can request personnel from federal agencies to assist in its duties. Members serve without pay but receive travel expenses. The Chairman can appoint staff without following standard government hiring procedures. The Veterans Expedited Recovery Commission can hire personnel as federal employees under specific regulations. The Commission may also enter into contracts to fulfill its duties as outlined in the Act. The Veterans Expedited Recovery Commission can hire experts and consultants, use postal services, and request administrative support services from the Administrator of General Services to fulfill its duties under the Act. The Veterans Expedited Recovery Commission can request administrative support services from the Administrator of General Services for human resource management, budget, leasing, accounting, and payroll services under this Act. The Veterans Expedited Recovery Commission can request administrative support services from the Administrator of General Services for human resource management, budget, leasing, accounting, and payroll services under this Act. SEC. 5. REPORT. The Veterans Expedited Recovery Commission must submit interim reports every 30 days detailing the level of cooperation from the Secretary of Veterans Affairs and other government departments. These reports are to be sent to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs of the House of Representatives, the Senate, and the President. The Veterans Expedited Recovery Commission will provide an interim report to the Senate and other relevant entities, followed by a final report within 18 months. The final report will include recommendations for implementing solutions, an analysis of the therapy model used by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, and an examination of the use of prescription drugs for treating mental health issues in veterans. The Veterans Expedited Recovery Commission will provide an interim report to the Senate and other relevant entities, followed by a final report within 18 months. The final report will include recommendations for implementing solutions, an analysis of the therapy model used by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, an examination of prescription drugs for treating mental health issues, and a plan for implementing the Commission's recommendations. The Commission will provide recommendations for implementing solutions to improve wellness-based outcomes for veterans with mental health issues, including a feasible timeframe for implementing alternative treatments Department-wide. If the Secretary deems the recommendations not appropriate, a justification and alternative solution to enhance the therapy model for treating veterans with mental health issues must be provided. The Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting the final report under section 5(b).
